contexts: 8 Information to be included on the label (2) (f) The presentation of the critical health information, and any information mentioned in paragraphs 8(2)(c), 8(2)(d) or 8(2)(e) that is included, must be presented in black or other dark coloured texts, using only one colour, on a white or other contrasting background.

6 Interpretation. "herbal material" means a plant or part of a plant (defined by its botanical scientific name according to the binominal nomenclature system, including author, and the plant part), whether fresh or dried, that is whole, fragmented, cut or ground;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine label includes the critical health information specified in paragraphs 8(2)(c), 8(2)(d) and 8(2)(e), what color text and background must be used to present this information according to section 8(2)(f)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Black text on a white background
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(f) states that the critical health information and any information from 8(2)(c), 8(2)(d) or 8(2)(e) must be presented in black or other dark colored text, using only one color, on a white or other contrasting background.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Given the definition of 'herbal material' in section 6, if a non-prescription medicine label lists Matricaria chamomilla L. flower as an ingredient, is this considered listing by 'herbal material' according to the regulations?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 defines 'herbal material' as a plant or plant part defined by its botanical scientific name according to the binomial nomenclature system, including author, and the plant part. Matricaria chamomilla L. flower specifies the scientific name, author (L. for Linnaeus), and plant part (flower), so it qualifies as an 'herbal material' listing.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a non-prescription medicine label includes the critical health information required by 8(2)(f), but presents it in red text on a black background. Does this comply with the text and background color requirements laid out in section 8(2)(f)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(f) mandates that the critical health information must be presented in black or dark colored text, using only one color, on a white or contrasting background. Red text on a black background uses two colors and the background is not white or contrasting, so this does not comply with 8(2)(f).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based on the definition in section 6, if a non-prescription medicine label lists Zingiber officinale as an ingredient without specifying the plant part, does this meet the criteria for listing by 'herbal material'?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 states that an 'herbal material' listing must include the botanical scientific name according to the binomial system, the author citation, and the specific plant part. While Zingiber officinale is a valid scientific name, the label does not specify the author or plant part. Therefore, it does not fully meet the 'herbal material' definition from section 6.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "Regulations" means the Therapeutic Goods Regulations 1990;
6 Interpretation. "composite pack" has the same meaning as in the Act;

10 Qualifications and special requirements (1) Preparations for ophthalmic use In addition to the requirements of sections 8 and 9 above, if a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use, the label on the container and on the primary pack or, where subsection 10(7) applies, the primary pack, must include: (a) the name of any antimicrobial preservative in the medicine;

9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (b) where the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names and the quantities or proportions of the active ingredients may be included on a side panel or side label or on a rear panel or rear label, when displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use, is registered goods, contains five active ingredients, and section 8(2) does not apply, what information must be included on the label and where should it be placed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of any antimicrobial preservative and the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be included on the label. The antimicrobial preservative name must be on the container label and primary pack label. The active ingredient names and quantities/proportions may be on a side or rear panel/label in text size of at least 2.5 mm.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(1)(a) requires the name of any antimicrobial preservative to be on the container and primary pack labels for ophthalmic preparations, in addition to sections 8 and 9 requirements. Section 9(7)(b) allows the active ingredient names and quantities/proportions to be on a side or rear panel/label in at least 2.5 mm text size if the medicine is registered goods, contains four or more active ingredients, and section 8(2) does not apply.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a registered medicine that is a preparation for ophthalmic use containing three active ingredients, assuming section 8(2) does not apply, what information must be on the main label and in what text size?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names and quantities or proportions of the three active ingredients must be included on the main label in text size of at least 1.5 mm. The name of any antimicrobial preservative must also be on the main label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7) only allows active ingredient names and quantities/proportions to be on a side or rear panel/label if the medicine contains four or more active ingredients. With three active ingredients, this information must be on the main label, assumed in the default text size of at least 1.5 mm from section 8. Section 10(1)(a) additionally requires the antimicrobial preservative name to be on the main label for ophthalmic preparations.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an ophthalmic preparation medicine is not registered goods but contains an antimicrobial preservative, what information must be included on the label and where should it be placed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the antimicrobial preservative must be included on the container label and on the primary pack label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(1)(a) requires the name of any antimicrobial preservative to be on the container and primary pack labels for ophthalmic preparations, regardless of the registered goods status or number of active ingredients. This is in addition to the section 8 and 9 labelling requirements.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a registered ophthalmic preparation medicine with five active ingredients, assuming section 8(2) applies, where must the active ingredient names and quantities be placed on the label and in what minimum text size?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be on the main label in text size of at least 1.5 mm. The name of any antimicrobial preservative must also be on the main label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Although the medicine contains more than four active ingredients, section 9(7)(b) only allows the active ingredient details to be on a side or rear panel/label if section 8(2) does not apply. Since section 8(2) is assumed to apply here, the active ingredient names and quantities must remain on the main label in the default minimum 1.5 mm text size. Section 10(1)(a) additionally requires the antimicrobial preservative name on the main label for ophthalmic preparations.

contexts: 4 Transition arrangements (2) On and from 1 September 2020, each medicine to which this Order applies must comply with the requirements specified in this Order.
6 Interpretation. "homoeopathic preparation" has the same meaning as in the Regulations.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a homoeopathic preparation medicine does not comply with the requirements of this Order as of 1 September 2020, what are the consequences for that medicine according to the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine is not allowed to be sold or supplied.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 4(2) states that as of 1 September 2020, each medicine to which this Order applies must comply with the requirements specified. Section 6 defines 'homoeopathic preparation' as having the same meaning as in the Regulations, indicating homoeopathic preparations are covered by this Order. Therefore, a non-compliant homoeopathic preparation cannot be legally supplied from the stated date onwards.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based on the definition provided in Section 6, if a product meets the Regulations' definition of a 'homoeopathic preparation' on 1 September 2020, which specific section requires it to comply with all requirements of this Order from that date?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Section 4(2)
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 states that 'homoeopathic preparation' has the same meaning as in the Regulations. Section 4(2) then specifies that on and from 1 September 2020, each medicine to which this Order applies must comply with its requirements. Connecting the two sections, this means any 'homoeopathic preparation' as defined in the Regulations must be fully compliant with the Order's requirements starting 1 September 2020.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a homoeopathic preparation, as defined in the Regulations per Section 6, does not meet all of this Order's requirements on 1 September 2020. According to Section 4(2), is it legal to supply that non-compliant medicine on or after that date?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 incorporates the Regulations' definition of 'homoeopathic preparation' for the purposes of this Order. Section 4(2) mandates that as of 1 September 2020, every medicine under the Order's scope must fully comply with the Order. Thus, supplying a homoeopathic preparation that fails to satisfy all of the Order's requirements would be prohibited on or after the stated compliance date, based on the combined effect of Sections 4(2) and 6.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Under the definitions provided in Section 6, would a medicine classified as a 'homoeopathic preparation' in the Regulations still be legal to supply if it does not fulfill this Order's stipulations after the date given in Section 4(2)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, it would be illegal to supply
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 4(2) sets 1 September 2020 as the date by which all medicines covered by this Order must meet its conditions to be supplied legally. Section 6 clarifies that 'homoeopathic preparation' takes on the same meaning as in the Regulations for the Order's purposes. Accordingly, any 'homoeopathic preparation' that does not satisfy the Order's requirements would be prohibited from being supplied on or after 1 September 2020, as Sections 4(2) and 6 interact to bring such medicines under the Order's scope and compliance deadline.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "composite pack" has the same meaning as in the Act;

8 Information to be included on the label (4) If the information required on the label on the container is obscured by intermediate packaging, then the label on the intermediate packaging must include: (f) the name of the sponsor or distributor, or a registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor of the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine has both a container label and intermediate packaging label, and the sponsor name is only included on the intermediate packaging label, does this meet the labeling requirements in the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(4)(f) states that if the container label information is obscured by intermediate packaging, the intermediate packaging label must include the name of the sponsor or distributor. Therefore, as long as the sponsor name is on the intermediate packaging label, it meets the requirements even if not on the container label itself.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is sold in a composite pack, and the composite pack meets the definition in the Act, do the labeling requirements in Section 8 apply to the composite pack?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 states that 'composite pack' has the same meaning as in the Act. Section 8 specifies labeling requirements, but does not mention anything about composite packs. Therefore, without more information from other sections, the labeling requirements in Section 8 cannot be assumed to apply to composite packs just based on the definition provided in Section 6.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine has a registered trademark that readily identifies the sponsor, can the trademark be used instead of the actual sponsor name on the intermediate packaging label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(4)(f) allows using 'a registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor of the medicine' on the intermediate packaging label instead of the actual sponsor/distributor name. Section 6 is not directly relevant to this question.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine composite pack has its container label information obscured by the intermediate packaging, does the intermediate packaging label need to include the sponsor name?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 establishes that 'composite pack' has the meaning given in the Act for this regulation. Section 8(4) states that if the container label is obscured by intermediate packaging, the intermediate packaging label must include the sponsor/distributor name or registered trademark. Taken together, this means composite packs are subject to the Section 8(4) labeling requirements for intermediate packaging obscuring the container label.

contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (f) for pressurised metered dose inhalers, dry powder inhalers and other metered dose products such as nasal sprays, the quantity of the active ingredient is: (i) the quantity delivered per actuation; or where the Secretary, when registering the medicine, has accepted that the dose of products containing those active ingredients was clinically established as the metered dose, then: (ii) the quantity metered per actuation;

6 Interpretation. "name of the medicine" means the following:(a) where the medicine is intended to be, or is, entered in the Register - the name of the medicine intended to appear or appearing on the Certificate of Registration or Certificate of Listing in relation to the medicine, not including the following information:(iii) the dosage form (except where this is integral to differentiate medicines from other medicines);

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be entered in the Register and it is a pressurized metered dose inhaler containing an active ingredient where the dose was clinically established as the metered dose, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label according to the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity metered per actuation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(f), for pressurised metered dose inhalers, the quantity of the active ingredient is the quantity delivered per actuation. However, section 11(2)(f)(ii) states that if the Secretary has accepted that the dose was clinically established as the metered dose when registering the medicine, then the quantity should be expressed as the quantity metered per actuation. Section 6(a) clarifies that 'name of the medicine' refers to the name intended to appear on the Certificate of Registration for a medicine intended to be entered in the Register.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a dry powder inhaler and is intended to be entered in the Register, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label if the dosage form is not integral to differentiate it from other medicines?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity delivered per actuation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(f)(i), for dry powder inhalers, the quantity of the active ingredient is the quantity delivered per actuation. Section 6(a) states that for a medicine intended to be entered in the Register, the 'name of the medicine' is the name intended to appear on the Certificate of Registration, not including the dosage form unless it is integral to differentiate medicines from other medicines. Therefore, even if the dosage form is not included in the name, the quantity should still be expressed as per section 11(2)(f)(i).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a nasal spray that has been accepted by the Secretary to have its dose clinically established as the metered dose during registration, and the medicine is intended to be entered in the Register, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label if the dosage form is not used to differentiate it from other medicines?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity metered per actuation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(2)(f) states that for other metered dose products such as nasal sprays, the quantity of the active ingredient is the quantity delivered per actuation. However, section 11(2)(f)(ii) provides an exception - if the Secretary has accepted that the dose was clinically established as the metered dose when registering the medicine, then the quantity should be expressed as the quantity metered per actuation. Section 6(a) clarifies that for a medicine intended to be entered in the Register, the dosage form is not included in the 'name of the medicine' unless it is integral to differentiate medicines from other medicines.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a pressurized metered dose inhaler containing an active ingredient is intended to be entered in the Register, and the dosage form is not used to differentiate it from other medicines, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label if the Secretary has not accepted that the dose was clinically established as the metered dose during registration?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity delivered per actuation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(f)(i), for pressurised metered dose inhalers, the quantity of the active ingredient is the quantity delivered per actuation, unless the Secretary has accepted that the dose was clinically established as the metered dose when registering the medicine, as per section 11(2)(f)(ii). Since this exception does not apply in the given scenario, the general rule in section 11(2)(f)(i) should be followed. Section 6(a) states that for a medicine intended to be entered in the Register, the dosage form is not included in the 'name of the medicine' unless it is integral to differentiate medicines from other medicines, but this does not affect how the quantity is expressed under section 11(2)(f).

contexts: 5 Exemptions – Medicines to which this Order does not apply  This Order does not apply to a medicine that is:(q) blood products under Item 13 that are described under paragraphs (a) and (b) under the heading ‘HUMAN BLOOD PRODUCTS’ in Appendix A to the Poisons Standard.

9 Information to be included on the main label (14) To avoid doubt, an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 must be included on the main label of a medicine containing that ingredient in accordance with the Australian Approved Names List for medicine released for supply on or after 1 May 2028.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains blood products that are described under paragraphs (a) and (b) under the heading 'HUMAN BLOOD PRODUCTS' in Appendix A to the Poisons Standard, and does not meet any other exemption criteria, does the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 92 apply to the labelling requirements for this medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 92 does not apply to the labelling requirements for this medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 5(q) states that the Order does not apply to a medicine that contains "blood products under Item 13 that are described under paragraphs (a) and (b) under the heading 'HUMAN BLOOD PRODUCTS' in Appendix A to the Poisons Standard." Since the medicine in question meets this exemption criteria and no other exemption is applicable, the Order and its labelling requirements do not apply to this medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is released for supply on or after 1 May 2028 and contains an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2, does section 9(14) require the ingredient name on the main label to match the Australian Approved Names List?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the ingredient name on the main label must match the Australian Approved Names List.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(14) states "To avoid doubt, an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 must be included on the main label of a medicine containing that ingredient in accordance with the Australian Approved Names List for medicine released for supply on or after 1 May 2028." Therefore, for a medicine meeting those criteria, the active ingredient name on the main label is required to match the name in the Australian Approved Names List.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains blood products described under paragraphs (a) and (b) under 'HUMAN BLOOD PRODUCTS' in Appendix A to the Poisons Standard, is released for supply after 1 May 2028, and contains an active ingredient in Part 2 of Schedule 2, is the ingredient required to be named on the main label per the Australian Approved Names List?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the active ingredient is not required to be named on the main label per the Australian Approved Names List.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: While section 9(14) generally requires active ingredients in Part 2 of Schedule 2 to be named on the main label per the Australian Approved Names List for medicines supplied after 1 May 2028, section 5(q) exempts medicines with certain blood products from the Order entirely. Since this medicine meets the 5(q) exemption, the Order and section 9(14)'s labelling requirement do not apply, even though the medicine otherwise meets 9(14)'s criteria.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is released for supply before 1 May 2028, contains an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2, and does not qualify for any exemptions under section 5, is the active ingredient required to be named on the main label in accordance with the Australian Approved Names List?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the active ingredient is not required to be named on the main label in accordance with the Australian Approved Names List.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(14) only requires active ingredients specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 to be named on the main label per the Australian Approved Names List for medicines released for supply on or after 1 May 2028. Since this medicine is supplied before that date and does not qualify for any section 5 exemptions, section 9(14)'s requirement does not apply, even though the medicine contains a Part 2 of Schedule 2 ingredient.

4 Transition arrangements (1) On and from 31 August 2016 and before 1 September 2020, each medicine to which this Order applies must comply with either:(b) the requirements specified in:(ii) Therapeutic Goods Order No. 69 - General Requirements for Labels for Medicines 2017 (TGO 69 (2017)), on or after 1 July 2017.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label is being created on 1 January 2018 and no other information about the medicine is known, which Therapeutic Goods Order must the medicine label comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 4(1)(b)(ii) states that on or after 1 July 2017, medicine labels must comply with Therapeutic Goods Order No. 69 - General Requirements for Labels for Medicines 2017 (TGO 69 (2017)). Since the label is being created on 1 January 2018, it falls into this date range and must comply with TGO 69 (2017).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label was created on 1 January 2017, which Therapeutic Goods Order was the label required to comply with at that time?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: TGO 69
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 4(1)(b)(i) states that up until 30 June 2017 (inclusive), medicine labels must comply with Therapeutic Goods Order No. 69 General requirements for labels for medicines (TGO 69). Since the label was created on 1 January 2017, it falls into this date range and was required to comply with TGO 69 at that time.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming today's date is 15 March 2020, which Therapeutic Goods Orders are valid options for a medicine label to comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 4(1) states the transition arrangements are in effect before 1 September 2020. Section 4(1)(b)(ii) specifies that on or after 1 July 2017, medicine labels must comply with TGO 69 (2017). Since 15 March 2020 falls between 1 July 2017 and 1 September 2020, TGO 69 (2017) is the only valid option for a medicine label to comply with on this date.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label was created on 30 June 2017, which Therapeutic Goods Orders would have been valid for the label to comply with on that date?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: TGO 69 or TGO 69 (2017)
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Sections 4(1)(b)(i) and (ii) provide two options for medicine label compliance on 30 June 2017. Section 4(1)(b)(i) allows compliance with TGO 69 up until 30 June 2017 (inclusive). Section 4(1)(b)(ii) allows compliance with TGO 69 (2017) on or after 1 July 2017. Since 30 June 2017 is both included in the first date range and is immediately before the second, a label created on that date could validly comply with either TGO 69 or TGO 69 (2017).

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (9) Strip, blister and dial dispenser packs (c) In addition to the requirements referred to in paragraphs 10(9)(a) and (b) as relevant, if each dosage unit is enclosed in the strip or blister such that an individual segment containing the dosage unit can be readily detached, then the following information must appear on the label of the strip or blister at least once in relation to every two dosage units: (i) for a medicine to which paragraph 10(9)(a) applies – the name of the medicine, the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine and the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine; and (ii) for a medicine to which paragraph 10(9)(b) applies – the name of the medicine.

4 Transition arrangements (1) On and from 31 August 2016 and before 1 September 2020, each medicine to which this Order applies must comply with either:(a) the requirements specified in this Order; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine to which paragraph 10(9)(a) applies is packaged in a strip or blister pack where each dosage unit is enclosed such that an individual segment containing the dosage unit can be readily detached, what information must appear on the label of the strip or blister at least once in relation to every two dosage units?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine, the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine, and the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 10(9)(c)(i), for a medicine to which paragraph 10(9)(a) applies, if each dosage unit is enclosed in a strip or blister such that an individual segment containing the dosage unit can be readily detached, then the name of the medicine, the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine, and the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine must appear on the label of the strip or blister at least once in relation to every two dosage units.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine to which paragraph 10(9)(b) applies is packaged in a strip or blister pack where each dosage unit is enclosed such that an individual segment containing the dosage unit can be readily detached, what information must appear on the label of the strip or blister at least once in relation to every two dosage units?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 10(9)(c)(ii), for a medicine to which paragraph 10(9)(b) applies, if each dosage unit is enclosed in a strip or blister such that an individual segment containing the dosage unit can be readily detached, then the name of the medicine must appear on the label of the strip or blister at least once in relation to every two dosage units.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming it is currently 15 October 2018, and a medicine is subject to the requirements of this Order, which set of requirements must the medicine comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine must comply with either the requirements specified in this Order, or the requirements that were in force immediately before 31 August 2016.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 4(1), on and from 31 August 2016 and before 1 September 2020, each medicine to which this Order applies must comply with either: (a) the requirements specified in this Order; or (b) the requirements that were in force immediately before 31 August 2016. Since the given date of 15 October 2018 falls within the range of 31 August 2016 to 1 September 2020, the medicine has the option to comply with either set of requirements.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming it is currently 2 November 2020, and a medicine is subject to the requirements of this Order, which set of requirements must the medicine comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine must comply with the requirements specified in this Order.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 4(1), the option to comply with either the requirements specified in this Order or the requirements that were in force immediately before 31 August 2016 only applies on and from 31 August 2016 and before 1 September 2020. Since the given date of 2 November 2020 is after 1 September 2020, the medicine must comply with the requirements specified in this Order.

11 How information is to be expressed (4) Permitted statements of storage temperature conditions For the purposes of this Order, the following statements of storage temperature conditions are permitted: (i) ‘Store below –18oC (Deep freeze)’; (ii) ‘Store below –5oC (Freeze)’; (iii) ‘Store at 2oC to 8oC (Refrigerate. Do not freeze)’; (iv) ‘Store below 25oC’; (v) ‘Store below 30oC’; (vi) for a medicine that is, or is intended to be, registered goods, any other storage temperature conditions as specified in the approved product details in relation to the medicine.
9 Information to be included on the main label (4) All text required by this Order to be on the main label must be oriented in the same direction.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is intended to be registered goods, what storage temperature condition statement would be permitted on the label if the approved product details specify it should be stored at 10°C?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: If a non-prescription medicine intended to be registered goods has approved product details specifying storage at 10°C, the permitted storage temperature condition statement on the label would be 'Store at 10°C'.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(4)(vi) states that for a medicine intended to be registered goods, any storage temperature conditions specified in the approved product details are permitted. Since the approved product details specify 10°C, this exact temperature can be stated on the label per 11(4)(vi), rather than the more general temperature ranges like 'Store below 25°C' allowed by 11(4)(iv).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine label includes text required by the Order, such as the signal heading 'KEEP OUT OF REACH OF CHILDREN' and the storage temperature condition 'Store below 25°C', in what way must this required text be oriented on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: All text required by the Order to be on the main label of a non-prescription medicine, such as the signal heading 'KEEP OUT OF REACH OF CHILDREN' and the storage temperature condition 'Store below 25°C', must be oriented in the same direction on the label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(4) clearly states that all text required by the Order to be on the main label must be oriented in the same direction. The signal heading is required by Section 6, and the storage temperature condition of 'Store below 25°C' is permitted by Section 11(4)(iv), so they are both text required by the Order and therefore must be oriented the same way on the main label per 9(4).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine that is not intended to be registered goods must have its storage temperature displayed on the label, which one of the following would be a permitted statement: A) 'Store below 5°C (Refrigerate)', B) 'Store below 25°C', or C) 'Store below -5°C (Freeze)'?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: For a non-prescription medicine not intended to be registered goods that requires a storage temperature on its label, of the options provided, B) 'Store below 25°C' is the only permitted statement.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(4) lists the permitted statements of storage temperature conditions. 11(4)(iv) allows 'Store below 25°C', but there is no provision for 'Store below 5°C (Refrigerate)' as in option A. Option C's 'Store below -5°C (Freeze)' is permitted by 11(4)(ii), but 11(4)(vi) specifies that any storage temperature can only be used for medicines intended to be registered goods, which this one is not, so C is not permitted. Therefore B is the only allowed statement of the three.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an unregistered non-prescription medicine label must display a storage temperature and the medicine should be stored below -20°C, what would be the most appropriate permitted storage temperature condition statement to use on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: For an unregistered non-prescription medicine that should be stored below -20°C, the most appropriate permitted storage temperature condition statement for its label would be 'Store below -18°C (Deep freeze)'.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(4) provides the permitted statements of storage temperature conditions. For a medicine that should be stored below -20°C, 11(4)(i) 'Store below -18°C (Deep freeze)' is the most suitable, as -18°C is the lowest temperature specified. The medicine is unregistered, so the custom temperature condition provision in 11(4)(vi) only for registered goods does not apply. Therefore, of the available options, 'Store below -18°C (Deep freeze)' is most appropriate for this unregistered medicine that should be kept below -20°C.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "homoeopathic potency" means the dilution factor of a homoeopathic preparation, expressed as: (a) (b) \"nX\" where each dilution is a decimal or ten-fold dilution and \"n\" is the number of dilutions such that the total dilution is 10n; or \"nC\" where each dilution is a centesimal or hundred-fold dilution and \"n\" is the number of dilutions such that the total dilution is 100n; or (c) \"nLM\" or \"LMn\" where, from a 3C starting dilution, each subsequent dilution is a fifty millesimal or fifty thousand fold dilution and \"n\" is the number of dilutions such that the total dilution is 50,000^n. Note: Where 1000 centesimal dilutions are performed, the potency is expressed as nM; that is, 1M potency represents a 1,000C dilution, 2M a 2,000C dilution, etc
6 Interpretation. "container" has the same meaning as in the Act;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming all information needed to answer the question is contained in the provided regulation sections, what is the total dilution factor for a homoeopathic preparation with potency expressed as "4C"?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The total dilution factor is 100^4.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 6, for a potency expressed as "nC", each dilution is a centesimal or hundred-fold dilution and "n" is the number of dilutions such that the total dilution is 100^n. In this case, with a potency of "4C", n=4, so the total dilution factor is 100^4.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the definition of "container" is limited to what is provided in the given regulation sections, what is the meaning of "container" in the context of these regulations?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: "Container" has the same meaning as in the Act.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 directly states that ""container" has the same meaning as in the Act". No other information about the meaning of "container" is provided in the given regulation sections.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based only on the information in the provided regulation sections, if a homoeopathic preparation has undergone 2000 centesimal dilutions, how would its potency be expressed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The potency would be expressed as 2M.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 states that "Where 1000 centesimal dilutions are performed, the potency is expressed as nM; that is, 1M potency represents a 1,000C dilution, 2M a 2,000C dilution, etc". So for 2000 centesimal dilutions, the potency is expressed as 2M.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Considering only the details provided in the given regulation sections, what is the total dilution factor for a preparation with potency "2LM", and what is the dilution factor for each dilution step?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: For a "2LM" potency, the dilution factor for each dilution step is fifty thousand (50,000), and the total dilution factor is 50,000^2.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 specifies that for a potency expressed as "nLM" or "LMn", each subsequent dilution starting from a 3C dilution is a fifty millesimal or fifty thousand fold dilution, and "n" is the number of dilutions such that the total dilution is 50,000^n. So for "2LM", there are 2 dilution steps each with a factor of 50,000, resulting in a total dilution of 50,000^2.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (b) not be separated by any text or graphics, except where additional information is: (i) required or permitted by: (A) paragraph 11(2)(h); or (B) subparagraphs 11(2)(i)(i) or 11(2)(i)(ii)(A); or (C) subsection 11(5); or (ii) in relation to identifying the different formulations of the medicines contained in a composite pack or a medicine kit;
6 Interpretation. "Poisons Standard" means the current Poisons Standard as defined in section 52A of the Act;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the Poisons Standard defined in section 52A of the Act includes the medicine 'X', which contains the active ingredient 'Y', what are the requirements for the name of 'X' and 'Y' on the main label according to paragraph 9(3)(b)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of medicine 'X' and active ingredient 'Y' must not be separated by any text or graphics on the main label, with some exceptions.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 9(3)(b), the name of the medicine and active ingredient(s) on the main label must not be separated by any text or graphics, except where additional information is permitted or required by specific sections and paragraphs listed in 9(3)(b)(i) and 9(3)(b)(ii). The Poisons Standard defined in section 6 is assumed to include medicine 'X' with active ingredient 'Y'.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming medicine 'X' is in a composite pack and its different formulations need to be identified on the main label, can the name of 'X' and its active ingredient 'Y' be separated by this identifying information according to paragraph 9(3)(b)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the name of medicine 'X' and active ingredient 'Y' can be separated by information identifying the different formulations of 'X' in a composite pack.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 9(3)(b)(ii) provides an exception allowing the name of the medicine and active ingredient(s) to be separated by information relating to identifying the different formulations of the medicines in a composite pack. Section 6 defines the Poisons Standard which is assumed to include medicine 'X' with active ingredient 'Y'.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If medicine 'ABC' is listed in the current Poisons Standard defined in section 52A of the Act and contains the active ingredients 'X', 'Y' and 'Z', can the name 'ABC' be separated from 'X', 'Y' and 'Z' on the main label by the information required in paragraph 11(2)(h)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the name of medicine 'ABC' can be separated from the names of active ingredients 'X', 'Y' and 'Z' by the information required in paragraph 11(2)(h).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 9(3)(b)(i)(A) allows the name of the medicine and active ingredient(s) to be separated by text or graphics where the additional information is required or permitted by paragraph 11(2)(h). Section 6 defines the Poisons Standard, which is assumed to include medicine 'ABC' with active ingredients 'X', 'Y' and 'Z' based on the information given in the question.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the medicine 'MedX' is part of a medicine kit and is listed in the Poisons Standard defined in section 52A of the Act, can the information specified in subsection 11(5) separate the name 'MedX' from its active ingredient 'Chemical Y' on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the information specified in subsection 11(5) can separate the name 'MedX' from its active ingredient 'Chemical Y' on the main label of the medicine kit.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 9(3)(b)(i)(C) permits the name of the medicine and active ingredient(s) to be separated by the additional information specified in subsection 11(5). Since 'MedX' is assumed to be part of a medicine kit and included in the Poisons Standard defined in section 6, the information in subsection 11(5) can separate its name from the active ingredient 'Chemical Y' on the main label of the kit.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (6) Medicine kits The label on a package that, together with medicines, constitutes a medicine kit must include the following information: (g) an expiry date for the kit, being the earliest expiry date of the medicines within the kit, preceded by the expiry date prefix;

9 Information to be included on the main label (14) To avoid doubt, an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 must be included on the main label of a medicine containing that ingredient in accordance with the Australian Approved Names List for medicine released for supply on or after 1 May 2028.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine kit contains only medicines and no other items, and all medicines in the kit have different expiry dates, what expiry date should be put on the label of the medicine kit?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The earliest expiry date of the medicines within the kit.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(6)(g) states that the expiry date on the label of a medicine kit must be the earliest expiry date of the medicines within the kit, preceded by the expiry date prefix.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 and is being released for supply on or after 1 May 2028, what naming convention must be used for that active ingredient on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The active ingredient must be named in accordance with the Australian Approved Names List.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(14) states that an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 must be included on the main label of a medicine containing that ingredient in accordance with the Australian Approved Names List for medicine released for supply on or after 1 May 2028.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine kit is released for supply on 1 June 2028 and contains two medicines, one with an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 expiring on 1 Jan 2029, and another medicine expiring on 1 Dec 2028, what expiry date and ingredient naming convention is required on the kit label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The expiry date on the kit label should be 1 Dec 2028, and the active ingredient of the relevant medicine must be named according to the Australian Approved Names List.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Per section 10(6)(g), the kit expiry date must be the earliest expiry date of the medicines, which is 1 Dec 2028. Section 9(14) requires the active ingredient of the medicine with an ingredient from Part 2 of Schedule 2 to use the name from the Australian Approved Names List, since the kit is supplied after 1 May 2028.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine kit contains only medicines, one of which has an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2, and the kit is released for supply before 1 May 2028, what naming convention can be used for the active ingredient on the kit label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The active ingredient is not required to be named according to the Australian Approved Names List.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(14) only requires using the Australian Approved Names List for active ingredients in Part 2 of Schedule 2 for medicines released for supply on or after 1 May 2028. Since this kit is supplied before that date, this requirement does not apply.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (5) If the medicine contains: (c) if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, and (i) subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names, and quantities or proportions, of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres; or (ii) subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required.

6 Interpretation. "registration number" means the combination of numbers and letters that is required to be included on the label of medicines in a manner described in regulation 15 of the Regulations;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is registered goods and does not meet the criteria in subsection 8(2), what is the minimum text size required for displaying the names and quantities or proportions of active ingredients on the side or rear panel or label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 2.5 millimetres
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to regulation 9(5)(c)(i), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods and subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is registered goods and meets the criteria in subsection 8(2), are the requirements in paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) still applicable?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to regulation 9(5)(c)(ii), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required.

QuestionAnswers.Question: What is the term used to describe the combination of numbers and letters that is required to be included on the label of registered medicines as per regulation 15?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Registration number
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: As per regulation 6, 'registration number' means the combination of numbers and letters that is required to be included on the label of medicines in a manner described in regulation 15 of the Regulations.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is registered goods, meets the criteria in subsection 8(2), and has a registration number, is it required to display the names and quantities or proportions of active ingredients on the side or rear panel or label in a minimum text size?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to regulation 9(5)(c)(ii), if the medicine is registered goods and meets the criteria in subsection 8(2), compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required. Regulation 6 defines 'registration number' as the combination of numbers and letters required on labels of registered medicines per regulation 15. Therefore, a registered medicine meeting 8(2) criteria with a registration number does not need to display active ingredient names and quantities in a minimum text size on the side/rear label.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "Certificate of Listing", in relation to a medicine, means the certificate given to the applicant for listing of the medicine under subsection 26(4) or subsection 26A(9) of the Act in relation to that medicine;

11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (b) for a solid for ingestion, where there is no discrete dosage unit - as the quantity of the active ingredient contained in the stated weight of a suitable dose of the solid;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a solid ingestion medicine with no discrete dosage unit has a Certificate of Listing, what information must be included on the label regarding the active ingredients according to the regulation sections provided?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of each active ingredient contained in the stated weight of a suitable dose of the solid.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(b), for a solid for ingestion with no discrete dosage unit, the label must express the quantity of each active ingredient contained in the stated weight of a suitable dose of the solid. Section 6 defines 'Certificate of Listing' but does not affect the labeling requirement from 11(2)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a listed medicine that is a solid for ingestion with no discrete dosage unit, how should the proportion of active ingredients be expressed on the label based solely on the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must express the quantity of each active ingredient contained in the stated weight of a suitable dose of the solid medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(2)(b) directly states that for a solid for ingestion where there is no discrete dosage unit, the label must express the quantity of the active ingredient contained in the stated weight of a suitable dose. Section 6 mentioning the Certificate of Listing for a listed medicine does not impact this labeling requirement from 11(2)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Considering only sections 6 and 11(2)(b), what is required on the label for expressing the amount of active ingredients in a suitable dose of a listed solid ingestion medicine that lacks discrete dosage units?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must state the quantity of each active ingredient contained in the weight of a suitable dose of the solid medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 11(2)(b) requires that for a solid for ingestion with no discrete dosage units, the label expresses the quantity of active ingredient in the stated weight of a suitable dose. The Certificate of Listing defined in section 6 does not change this requirement from 11(2)(b) for expressing active ingredients on the label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based only on the provided regulation sections, how must a medicine's label state the active ingredient amounts for a solid ingestion medicine that has a Certificate of Listing but no discrete dosage units?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must express the quantity of each active ingredient contained in the stated weight of a suitable dose of the solid ingestion medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(2)(b) mandates that for a solid for ingestion lacking discrete dosage units, the label expresses the quantity of each active ingredient in the stated weight of a suitable dose. Having a Certificate of Listing per section 6 does not alter or override this labeling requirement from 11(2)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine has been listed under subsection 26(4) of the Act and a Certificate of Listing was issued, what is the meaning of the term 'primary pack' in relation to the medicine's packaging?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The term 'primary pack' has the same meaning as defined in the Act.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 of the Interpretation states that 'primary pack' has the same meaning as in the Act. Since the question assumes the medicine has been listed under subsection 26(4) of the Act and a Certificate of Listing was issued, the interpretation of 'primary pack' as defined in the Act applies to the medicine's packaging.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If an applicant receives a certificate under subsection 26A(9) of the Act for a medicine, can this certificate be referred to as a 'Certificate of Listing' based on the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the certificate given to the applicant under subsection 26A(9) of the Act can be referred to as a 'Certificate of Listing'.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The Interpretation section 6 defines 'Certificate of Listing' as the certificate given to the applicant for listing of the medicine under subsection 26(4) or subsection 26A(9) of the Act. Therefore, a certificate issued under either subsection 26(4) or 26A(9) is considered a 'Certificate of Listing' according to the provided regulation sections.

QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the term 'primary pack' can be interpreted based on its meaning in the Act when referring to the packaging of a medicine that has been issued a certificate under subsection 26(4) of the Act.

contexts: 5 Exemptions – Medicines to which this Order does not apply  This Order does not apply to a medicine that is:(i) imported for use in the treatment of the importer or the importer’s immediate family as set out in Item 1 of Schedule 5 to the Regulations; or

9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (a) appear as a cohesive unit by the placing of the name and quantity of each active ingredient together on separate lines of text either (i) immediately below the name of the medicine; or (ii) where the trademark of the medicine might be disrupted or obscured, adjacent to the name of the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is imported for personal use by an individual to treat themselves or their immediate family, and all the information required by Section 9(3)(a) is included on the main label, is the medicine exempt from the Order?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the medicine is exempt from the Order.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 5(i) states that the Order does not apply to a medicine imported for use in the treatment of the importer or the importer's immediate family. Section 9(3)(a) specifies the requirements for the name of the medicine and active ingredients on the main label. Since the question assumes the medicine is for personal/family use and meets the main label requirements, it would be exempt from the Order based on Section 5(i).

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a medicine is not imported for personal or immediate family use, can it be exempt from the Order even if the main label includes the name of the medicine and active ingredients as required by Section 9(3)(a)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the medicine would not be exempt from the Order in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 5(i) only provides an exemption for medicines imported for personal use by the importer or their immediate family. Section 9(3)(a) specifies labeling requirements but does not itself grant any exemption. So if the medicine is not for the allowed personal/family use, including the required information on the main label is not sufficient to make it exempt from the Order.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a medicine is imported by an individual for their own treatment. The main label properly shows the medicine name but lists the active ingredients on a line that does not immediately follow the name or is not adjacent to it. Is this medicine exempt from the Order?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, this medicine would not be exempt from the Order.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Although Section 5(i) exempts medicines imported for the importer's own use, Section 9(3)(a) requires the active ingredients to be listed either immediately below the medicine name or adjacent to it if placing them below would disrupt the trademark. By not meeting this formatting requirement, the medicine fails to satisfy the labeling conditions in 9(3)(a). Therefore, the exemption in Section 5(i) would not apply.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a medicine is imported by someone to treat their family member and the main label lists the active ingredients adjacent to the medicine name to avoid disrupting the trademark, is the medicine exempt from this Order?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the medicine is exempt from the Order in this situation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The medicine qualifies for the exemption in Section 5(i) since it is imported to treat the importer's immediate family. It also satisfies Section 9(3)(a) which allows the active ingredients to be placed adjacent to the medicine name on the label if putting them immediately below would disrupt the trademark. With both the exemption criteria and labeling requirement met, the medicine is not subject to the Order.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "complementary healthcare practitioner" means a person described in paragraph 42AA(1)(c) of the Act;

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (f) the batch number of the medicine preceded by the batch number prefix; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a complementary healthcare practitioner is preparing a medicine label in accordance with the regulation, does the label need to include the batch number of the medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(f) states that the labels of a medicine must include the batch number of the medicine preceded by the batch number prefix, subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10. Section 6 defines a complementary healthcare practitioner as a person described in paragraph 42AA(1)(c) of the Act. Therefore, a complementary healthcare practitioner preparing a medicine label must include the batch number as per 8(1)(f), unless an exception applies under 8(2), 8(3), 9 or 10.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based on the provided regulation sections, is a complementary healthcare practitioner as defined in section 6 required to include their name on the label of a medicine they prepare?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: It depends
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1) lists the information that must be included on medicine labels, subject to qualifications in 8(2), 8(3), 9 and 10. However, the name of the complementary healthcare practitioner is not listed as a requirement in 8(1). Section 6 provides the definition of a complementary healthcare practitioner, but does not itself impose any labelling requirements. Therefore, based solely on the provided sections, it cannot be definitively determined if the practitioner's name is required, as this may be specified in the sections not provided (8(2), 8(3), 9, 10 or elsewhere in the regulation).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a complementary healthcare practitioner following this regulation prepares a medicine. They include all the applicable information from section 8(1) on the label. Assuming sections 8(2), 8(3), 9 and 10 do not apply, is the practitioner fully compliant with the labelling requirements?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Unknown
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1) lists several pieces of information that must be included on a medicine label, such as the batch number (8(1)(f)). It also states that this is subject to subsections 8(2), 8(3), and sections 9 and 10. The question assumes the practitioner, defined in section 6, has included all applicable 8(1) information and that 8(2), 8(3), 9 and 10 do not apply. However, the regulation may contain additional labelling requirements beyond section 8, 9 and 10. Without the full regulation available, it cannot be determined with certainty if the practitioner is fully compliant by only satisfying section 8(1).

QuestionAnswers.Question: A complementary healthcare practitioner plans to prepare a medicine. They have read sections 6 and 8(1)(f) of the labelling regulation. Can they be certain that including the batch number will ensure full compliance with the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(f) mandates that the batch number must be on the label. However, 8(1) is subject to subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10, which may alter or remove the batch number requirement. Additionally, the regulation likely contains other labelling requirements not covered in the provided sections. The practitioner, defined in section 6, cannot assume that satisfying a single clause, 8(1)(f), will guarantee full compliance. They would need to carefully review the entire regulation to understand all applicable labelling requirements for their situation.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "delivered dose" means, in relation to: (a) metered dose preparations - the dose delivered to the patient in a single actuation or delivery; and (b) powders for inhalation - the dose delivered from the inhaler in a single delivery;

Introduction (2) The purpose of the label on a medicine is to provide information about the medicine such as its identity, potency, content, storage, expiry date, dose, directions for use, sponsor details and registration/listing status. Labels on medicines can also include other information not required by this Order but which may be required by other legislation or for commercial purposes such as the sponsor’s logo.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming 'metered dose preparations' and 'powders for inhalation' are types of medicines, what does the term 'delivered dose' mean for each type according to the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: For metered dose preparations, 'delivered dose' means the dose delivered to the patient in a single actuation or delivery. For powders for inhalation, 'delivered dose' means the dose delivered from the inhaler in a single delivery.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 of the regulation defines 'delivered dose' for both (a) metered dose preparations and (b) powders for inhalation. For (a), it is the dose delivered to the patient in a single actuation or delivery. For (b), it is the dose delivered from the inhaler in a single delivery.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based on the regulation's stated purpose of a medicine label, which of the following are required to be on the label: the medicine's identity, potency, content, storage instructions, expiry date, dose, directions for use, sponsor details, and registration/listing status?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: According to the regulation, all of the listed items are required to be on a medicine label: the medicine's identity, potency, content, storage instructions, expiry date, dose, directions for use, sponsor details, and registration/listing status.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The Introduction section (2) states: "The purpose of the label on a medicine is to provide information about the medicine such as its identity, potency, content, storage, expiry date, dose, directions for use, sponsor details and registration/listing status." This directly lists all the items in the question as being required on the label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a metered dose inhaler is a type of metered dose preparation, does the 'delivered dose' information required on the label refer to the total dose in the entire inhaler or the dose delivered in a single actuation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: For a metered dose inhaler, the 'delivered dose' information required on the label refers to the dose delivered to the patient in a single actuation or delivery, not the total dose in the entire inhaler.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6(a) defines 'delivered dose' for metered dose preparations as "the dose delivered to the patient in a single actuation or delivery". The Introduction section (2) states that the dose is required information on a medicine label. Therefore, for a metered dose inhaler, the required 'delivered dose' label information is the dose delivered in a single actuation, not the total inhaler dose.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Other than the information required by this regulation, can medicine labels include additional information? If so, for what purpose, according to the given sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, in addition to the information required by this regulation, medicine labels can include other information not required by this Order. According to Introduction section (2), this additional information may be required by other legislation or included for commercial purposes such as the sponsor's logo.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Introduction section (2), after listing the required medicine label information, states: "Labels on medicines can also include other information not required by this Order but which may be required by other legislation or for commercial purposes such as the sponsor's logo." This directly answers that labels can have additional non-required information for the purposes of other legislation or commercial reasons.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "stated volume of fill" means the volume of medicine that the container is specified by the sponsor to contain;
Introduction (1) This Order sets out what kinds of information are required to be included on the label of medicines of the kind described in section 3, and in what circumstances.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine container is labeled as containing 50mL, what does the "stated volume of fill" refer to according to the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 50mL
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 defines the "stated volume of fill" as "the volume of medicine that the container is specified by the sponsor to contain". In this case, the container is labeled as containing 50mL, so according to the definition in section 6, the "stated volume of fill" is 50mL.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based on the given regulation sections, if a non-prescription medicine meets the criteria outlined in section 3, what is required to be included on its label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The kinds of information specified in this Order
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The Introduction section (1) states that this Order sets out what kinds of information are required to be included on the label of medicines of the kind described in section 3. So for a non-prescription medicine that meets the section 3 criteria, the information specified in the Order must be included on its label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine falls under the scope of section 3 and has a labeled volume of 100mL, what volume is considered the "stated volume of fill" for this medicine based on the provided regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 100mL
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Since the medicine falls under section 3, the labeling requirements in this Order apply, according to section (1) in the Introduction. Section 6 defines the "stated volume of fill" as the labeled volume specified by the sponsor. With a labeled volume of 100mL, this matches the "stated volume of fill" definition in section 6.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a non-prescription medicine that is covered under section 3 and has a "stated volume of fill" of 200mL according to the sponsor, what information must be included on the medicine's label based on the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The kinds of information required by this Order
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section (1) in the Introduction specifies that for medicines of the kind described in section 3, this Order sets out what kinds of information must be on the label. Section 6 defines the "stated volume of fill" as the volume the sponsor specifies the container to contain. So for a section 3 medicine with a 200mL "stated volume of fill", the Order's required label information applies.

contexts: 8 Information to be included on the label (2) (e) If information other than the critical health information or information of a kind mentioned in subsections 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is to be included, it must be placed under the ‘Other information’ heading or under another separate appropriate heading(s) that follow immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b) and must not contain any additional information other than: A. requirements relating to storage conditions B. information about package features to prevent tampering C. names of all excipients D. sponsor or distributor contact details.

9 Information to be included on the main label (8) Where a medicine is: (d) the information required under either paragraph 9(6)(b) or subsection 9(7) must be provided separately in relation to each formulation of medicine in the composite pack or medicine kit.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label contains both critical health information and other information like storage conditions, package tamper prevention features, excipient names, and sponsor contact details, what heading should the other information be placed under according to the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The other information should be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another separate appropriate heading that follows immediately below the critical health information.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 8(2)(e), if information other than the critical health information is included on the label, it must be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another separate appropriate heading that follows immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b). The allowed other information includes storage conditions, package tamper prevention features, excipient names, and sponsor or distributor contact details.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Consider a composite pack or medicine kit containing multiple medicine formulations. What information is required to be provided separately for each formulation, assuming the requirements of either paragraph 9(6)(b) or subsection 9(7) apply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The information required under either paragraph 9(6)(b) or subsection 9(7) must be provided separately for each formulation of medicine in the composite pack or medicine kit.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(8)(d) states that where a medicine is a composite pack or medicine kit, the information required under either paragraph 9(6)(b) or subsection 9(7) must be provided separately in relation to each formulation of medicine in the pack or kit.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a non-prescription medicine label includes storage condition information under the 'Other information' heading, which follows immediately below the critical health information headings specified in 8(2)(b). Is this placement allowed by the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, placing the storage condition information under the 'Other information' heading that follows immediately below the critical health information headings is allowed by the regulation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(e) permits including storage condition information under the 'Other information' heading or another separate appropriate heading, as long as it follows immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b) which contain the critical health information.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a composite pack medicine containing multiple formulations, if the information required by paragraph 9(6)(b) is provided separately for each formulation as mandated by 9(8)(d), can this information be placed under the 'Other information' heading that follows the critical health information section per 8(2)(e)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the information required by paragraph 9(6)(b) for each formulation in a composite pack medicine cannot be placed under the 'Other information' heading. Section 8(2)(e) only allows specific types of other information to be included there, and the per-formulation information required by 9(6)(b) and 9(8)(d) is not listed among the permitted types.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(8)(d) requires the information under 9(6)(b) or 9(7) to be provided separately for each formulation in a composite pack medicine. However, 8(2)(e) restricts the 'Other information' section to only contain storage conditions, tamper prevention features, excipient names, and sponsor/distributor contact details. Therefore, the per-formulation information cannot be placed under 'Other information' and must be in its own section.

contexts: 4 Transition arrangements (1) On and from 31 August 2016 and before 1 September 2020, each medicine to which this Order applies must comply with either:(b) the requirements specified in:(i) Therapeutic Goods Order No. 69 General requirements for labels for medicines (TGO 69), up until 30 June 2017 (inclusive); or
Introduction (6) Guidelines to assist in the design of medicine labels are available on the Therapeutic Goods Administration website (http://www.tga.gov.au).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label was created on 1 December 2016 and the medicine is covered by Therapeutic Goods Order No. 92, which labelling requirements must it comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: TGO 69 or TGO 92
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 4(1), between 31 August 2016 and 1 September 2020, medicines must comply with either the requirements in TGO 92 or the requirements in TGO 69 up until 30 June 2017. Since the label was created on 1 December 2016, it falls in this transition period and has the option to comply with either TGO 69 or TGO 92.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Where can guidelines to assist in the design of medicine labels that comply with Therapeutic Goods Order No. 92 be found, according to the Introduction section?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Therapeutic Goods Administration website
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 of the Introduction states that guidelines to assist in the design of medicine labels are available on the Therapeutic Goods Administration website at the URL http://www.tga.gov.au.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is covered by Therapeutic Goods Order No. 92, do labels for this medicine created on 1 July 2017 have the option to comply with Therapeutic Goods Order No. 69?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 4(1) specifies that medicines have the option to comply with TGO 69 only up until 30 June 2017 (inclusive). Labels created on 1 July 2017 are after this cut-off date, so based on section 4(1), they do not have the option to comply with TGO 69 and must comply with TGO 92.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For medicines covered by Therapeutic Goods Order No. 92, is compliance with the label design guidelines on the Therapeutic Goods Administration website mandatory during the 31 August 2016 to 1 September 2020 transition period?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 of the Introduction states the label design guidelines are available on the TGA website, but section 4(1) on transition arrangements does not mention these guidelines. Section 4(1) only requires compliance with either TGO 92 or TGO 69 until 30 June 2017 during the transition period, with no mention of the guidelines being mandatory.
