contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (5) Inclusion of common names of vitamins Where a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, then the word ‘vitamin’, or any suitable unambiguous abbreviation of the word vitamin, together with the common name of that vitamin, may appear on a main label of the medicine either: (a) on the same line of text - between the approved name of the active ingredient that is a vitamin and the quantity of that active ingredient; or

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (m) if the medicine requires some preparation, such as dissolving, suspending, diluting or reconstituting before use - instructions for its preparation and, where relevant, a statement of the conditions of storage and the maximum period of storage between preparation and use, except where: (i) there is insufficient space on the label of either the container or the primary pack, or both, to include this information; and (ii) this information is set out in a package insert provided in the primary pack of the medicine; and (iii) a statement is included on whichever label on the container or the primary pack, or both, that does not set out the information itself, that this information is set out in the package insert; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, can the common name of the vitamin be included on the main label along with the word 'vitamin' or a suitable abbreviation? If so, where on the label in relation to the approved name and quantity of the vitamin ingredient can this information appear?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the common name of the vitamin can be included.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 11(5)(a), if a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, the word 'vitamin' or a suitable abbreviation, along with the common name of the vitamin, may appear on the main label either on the same line of text between the approved name of the vitamin ingredient and its quantity.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine requires preparation such as dissolving, suspending, diluting or reconstituting before use, under what conditions can the preparation instructions and storage conditions after preparation be omitted from the label and instead provided in a package insert?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The preparation instructions and storage conditions can be provided in a package insert if three conditions are met.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Per subsection 8(1)(m), preparation instructions and storage conditions between preparation and use can be provided in a package insert instead of on the label if: (i) there is insufficient label space on the container or primary pack, (ii) the information is in the package insert, and (iii) the label that lacks the information has a statement that it is in the package insert.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Given a non-prescription medicine that contains a vitamin as an active ingredient and requires preparation before use, is it acceptable for the preparation instructions to be provided in a package insert while the vitamin's common name appears on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, this is acceptable under the given conditions.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 11(5)(a) allows the vitamin's common name to appear on the main label between the approved name and quantity. Subsection 8(1)(m) permits preparation instructions to be in a package insert if the criteria in 8(1)(m)(i)-(iii) are satisfied. So the common name can be on the main label while preparation instructions are in an insert.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a non-prescription medicine containing a vitamin ingredient, is it required to include the word 'vitamin' or an abbreviation along with the vitamin's common name on the main label, or is this optional? Assume there is sufficient label space for preparation instructions if the medicine requires preparation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Including 'vitamin' or an abbreviation with the common name on the main label is optional, not required.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The wording in subsection 11(5) is 'may appear', indicating that including 'vitamin' or an abbreviation along with the common vitamin name is permitted but not mandatory on the main label. Since there is sufficient label space, subsection 8(1)(m) would require any needed preparation instructions to be on the label rather than a package insert.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (5) If the medicine contains: (b) at least two of those active ingredients belong to any of the following categories: (i) a vitamin that is identified by both: (A) the approved name of the active ingredient that is a vitamin; and (B) in accordance with subsection 11(5), the word ‘vitamin’, or any suitable unambiguous abbreviation of the word vitamin, together with the common name of that vitamin; or (ii) a mineral;  (iii) a herbal preparation that, under subparagraph 11(2)(i)(ii), is required to be quantified as either: (A) the dry or fresh weight of herbal material from which the preparation was derived; or (B) the minimum dry or fresh weight of herbal material from which the preparation was derived, then: the names, and quantities or proportions, of all active ingredients in the medicine may appear on a side panel or side label or on a rear panel or rear label instead of on the main label; and

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (a) Subject to paragraphs (b), (c) and (d), where the medicine is registered goods, the critical health information must be displayed on the label of the primary pack in a tabulated form.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine contains vitamins A and C as well as the mineral calcium, can the quantities of these active ingredients be listed on a side or rear label instead of the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(5)(b) states that if a medicine contains at least two active ingredients that belong to the categories of vitamins or minerals, the names and quantities of all active ingredients may appear on a side panel, side label, rear panel, or rear label instead of the main label. Since the medicine in question contains two vitamins (A and C) and a mineral (calcium), it meets this criteria and the quantities can be listed on a side or rear label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a registered non-prescription medicine, is it required that the critical health information be displayed in a tabulated form on the primary pack label, even if the medicine contains multiple vitamin and mineral ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: While section 8(2)(a) states that critical health information must generally be displayed in tabulated form on the primary pack label for registered medicines, section 9(5)(b) provides an exception. If the medicine contains at least two active ingredients that are vitamins or minerals, the quantities of all active ingredients may instead appear on a side or rear label. So in this case, the tabulated critical health information is not required on the primary pack label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a registered non-prescription medicine contains vitamins B and D, as well as herbal preparations that are required to be quantified by dry weight. Must the critical health information still appear in tabulated form on the primary pack label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(a) requires critical health information to be in tabulated form on the primary pack label for registered medicines, subject to some exceptions. One exception, outlined in 9(5)(b), is that if the medicine contains at least two active ingredients that are vitamins, minerals, or certain herbal preparations, then the names and quantities of all active ingredients may appear on a side or rear label instead. Since this medicine has two vitamins and qualifying herbal preparations, the exception applies and the tabulated information on the primary label is not required.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a non-prescription medicine containing vitamin C, vitamin E, and a herbal preparation quantified by minimum fresh weight, can the vitamin quantities be listed on the main label while the herbal quantity is on a side label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(5)(b) allows the quantities of all active ingredients to be listed on a side or rear label instead of the main label, if the medicine contains at least two ingredients that are vitamins, minerals, or certain herbal preparations. However, this applies to all active ingredient quantities - they must all be moved to the side/rear labels together. The medicine cannot have some active quantities on the main label and others on side/rear labels. Since this medicine qualifies for the 9(5)(b) exception with its two vitamins and herbal preparation, all three quantities must appear together on a side, rear, or main label.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (6) Medicine kits The label on a package that, together with medicines, constitutes a medicine kit must include the following information: (c) the name of each of the medicines within the kit and its dosage form;
6 Interpretation. "stated volume of fill" means the volume of medicine that the container is specified by the sponsor to contain;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming that a medicine kit contains three medicines in tablet form named 'Paracetamol', 'Ibuprofen', and 'Aspirin', what information must the label on the package of this medicine kit include according to the regulation sections 10(6)(c) and 6?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include the name of each medicine (Paracetamol, Ibuprofen, Aspirin) and its dosage form (tablet).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(6)(c) states that the label on a medicine kit package must include 'the name of each of the medicines within the kit and its dosage form'. Section 6 provides the definition of 'stated volume of fill', which is not directly relevant to answering this question about medicine names and dosage forms.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine kit contains a bottle of liquid medicine, and the sponsor specifies that the bottle should contain 100 mL of the medicine, what is this 100 mL quantity called according to the definition provided in section 6 of the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The 100 mL quantity is called the 'stated volume of fill'.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 provides the definition: ''stated volume of fill' means the volume of medicine that the container is specified by the sponsor to contain'. In this case, the sponsor has specified the bottle should contain 100 mL, so this is the 'stated volume of fill'. Section 10(6)(c) about labeling requirements for medicine kit packages is not directly relevant to answering this question about the definition of 'stated volume of fill'.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine kit contains 3 medicines - 'Paracetamol' in tablet form, 'Ibuprofen' in capsule form, and 'Cough Syrup' as a liquid with a stated volume of fill of 50 mL - what information about each medicine must be included on the package label for this kit based on the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The package label must include: 1) Paracetamol, dosage form: tablet 2) Ibuprofen, dosage form: capsule 3) Cough Syrup, dosage form: liquid, stated volume of fill: 50 mL
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(6)(c) requires the label to include 'the name of each of the medicines within the kit and its dosage form'. Section 6 defines 'stated volume of fill' as 'the volume of medicine that the container is specified by the sponsor to contain'. Combining these requirements, for each medicine the label must state the name, the dosage form, and for liquids the stated volume of fill.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine kit contains two medicines - 'Antibiotic Tablets' and a liquid 'Cough Syrup' - and the sponsor has not specified any volume of fill for the cough syrup bottle, what information must be included on the kit package label to comply with regulations 10(6)(c) and 6?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include: 1) 'Antibiotic Tablets', dosage form: tablet 2) 'Cough Syrup', dosage form: liquid. No stated volume of fill needs to be included on the label for the cough syrup.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(6)(c) requires the medicine kit label to include the name and dosage form of each medicine. This is 'Antibiotic Tablets' (dosage form: tablet) and 'Cough Syrup' (dosage form: liquid). Section 6 defines 'stated volume of fill', but since the sponsor has not specified any volume, this does not need to be included on the label. The label complies with 10(6)(c) by having the required names and dosage forms.

contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (5) Inclusion of common names of vitamins Where a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, then the word ‘vitamin’, or any suitable unambiguous abbreviation of the word vitamin, together with the common name of that vitamin, may appear on a main label of the medicine either: (b) on a separate line of text - immediately below the related name of the active ingredient that is a vitamin and the quantity of that active ingredient.

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (g) the expiry date of the medicine, preceded by the expiry date prefix; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains vitamin B6 as an active ingredient, what information can be included on the main label regarding the vitamin, and where should it be placed in relation to the ingredient name and quantity?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The main label may include the word 'vitamin' or a suitable abbreviation, along with the common name 'vitamin B6', either immediately below the ingredient name and quantity on a separate line, or in parentheses immediately following the quantity.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(5)(b) states that for a medicine containing a vitamin as an active ingredient, the word 'vitamin' or an abbreviation, together with the common name of the vitamin, may appear on the main label either 'on a separate line of text - immediately below the related name of the active ingredient that is a vitamin and the quantity of that active ingredient'.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming no other qualifications or requirements apply, what information must be included on the labels of a medicine according to the standard, and how should the expiry date be expressed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Subject to subsections 8(2), 8(3), and sections 9-10, medicine labels must include the expiry date, preceded by the expiry date prefix.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(g) states that 'Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (g) the expiry date of the medicine, preceded by the expiry date prefix'.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains thiamine (vitamin B1) as an active ingredient and no other label requirements apply, what text could be included on the main label to indicate this, and where should the text be positioned?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The main label could include the text 'vitamin B1' either in parentheses immediately following the quantity of thiamine, or on a separate line immediately below the thiamine ingredient name and quantity.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(5)(b), for a medicine containing a vitamin, the word 'vitamin' or an abbreviation along with the vitamin's common name (B1 for thiamine) may be included on the main label, positioned either immediately below the ingredient name and quantity on a separate line, or in parentheses right after the quantity. Section 8(1) subjects this to subsections 8(2), 8(3) and sections 9-10.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a medicine with an active ingredient that is a vitamin, assuming the standard labelling requirements apply and no other provisions are relevant, what information about the vitamin may be provided on the main label and how should the medicine's expiry date be indicated?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The main label may state the word 'vitamin' or an abbreviation, along with the vitamin's common name, either in parentheses after the ingredient quantity or on a separate line below the ingredient name and amount. The expiry date must be included on the label, with the expiry date prefix before the date.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(5)(b) allows the word 'vitamin' and the vitamin's common name to be included on the main label in the specified positions relative to the ingredient details. Per section 8(1)(g), subject to 8(2), 8(3), 9 and 10, the expiry date preceded by the expiry date prefix must be on the medicine labels.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (c) if the medicine is: (i) supplied in either a small or a medium container; and (ii) contains multiple active ingredients then, in relation to compliance of the label with paragraph 9(3)(a), the names of the multiple active ingredients and their quantities may be presented together on a continuous line, or lines, of text.

Introduction (5) This Order also sets out general requirements for the labels of non- prescription medicines. The purpose of the Order is to facilitate the quality use of those medicines by consumers and health professionals by ensuring appropriate labelling. Consideration of the following objectives in designing labels, and assessing and determining compliance with the requirements of this Order, will assist in achieving that purpose: - minimising the risk of prescribing, dispensing and self-selection errors; - enhancing consumer safety; - avoiding consumer confusion and the inappropriate use of medicines (including misuse, over-use, and under-use); - assisting the appropriate selection of those medicines; - assisting the safe and effective use of those medicines; - optimising identification and usability of necessary information; - improving consumers’ ability to solve problems related to those medicines, such as managing multiple medicines; and - where relevant, ensuring consumers are aware of where to go for further information about their medicine.
